metadata.h1: Academia To Data Science: Transferable Skills

all_paragraphs: 12 weeks ago, I decided to quit my job as a postdoctoral researcher in academia and joined a 12-week data science immersive bootcamp (you guessed it! the bootcamp is almost over!!🎉).
This career switch wasn’t an easy decision on my end. In my previous blog post, I explain the reasons that led me to this decision.

As someone who spent most of his professional career in academia, I was a bit intimidated to enter the world of data science thinking that I might lack the necessary skills to succeed as a data scientist.

Now, 12 weeks later, I realized how wrong my doubts were. In fact, I was surprised that many of the skills that I developed in academia were transferable and a key to my success as a data scientist fellow.
Here, I am going to share the top 5 transferrable skills that I found very useful.

As researchers in academia, we work with data on a daily basis. This includes data collection, cleaning, analysis, and visualization. Having these skills is extremely helpful in order to succeed as a data scientist (as the name implies!).

Sure you might still feel intimidated, especially if you don’t have any experience with coding languages, and to be perfectly honest, I felt the same at first, but I quickly realized that learning how to code (particularly using python) is easy, but learning how to work with data is hard.
So cheer up! you already got the hardest part! 🥳

In a way, this skill is an extension of the data handling skills. Performing statistical analysis on collected data is a very frequent routine in research. This is where we try to make sense of our data to reveal interesting trends and patterns and analyze differences between groups. As a data scientist, it’s vital to have a solid grasp of statistics and statistical methods.
Here is a great book for statistical learning methods if you feel the need to brush up on your statistical analysis skill.
The field of data science is ever-changing. To be distinguished as a successful data scientist, you’ll need to keep up with the literature.

Luckily, in academia, we get extensive training and experience on how to research, read, and keep up with the current literature. Although the literature of data science might be distinct from what we’d been used to in academia (in my case neuroscience), having these skills will significantly speed up your learning process.

“Great literature should do some good to the reader: must quicken their perception though dull, and sharpen their discrimination though blunt, and mellow the rawness of their personal opinions.” -A. E. Housman

I can’t remember a time where my experiments worked perfectly on the first try. Most of the time, the experiments did not work as expected and I had to go back to the drawing board to figure out what went wrong and how to solve it.

I experienced the same pattern with data science. I hit many roadblocks while working on different projects and things just didn’t work perfectly right away. Your problem-solving and strategic thinking abilities will help you to identify the problem and work strategically to solve that on the next try.
Last but not least, effective communication skills.
Your work and findings as a data scientist will mean nothing if you don’t know how to properly and effectively communicate it to other people.

Thankfully, In academia, we learn how to effectively communicate and share our findings routinely through talks and poster presentations at national and international conferences. We’re also expected to share our work through written publications regularly.

Additionally, in academia, we are acquainted with communicating science not only to fellow scientists but also to the general public. in other words, we know how to simplify complicated concepts for non-technical people, which is one of the most important and hardest communication skills to have.
Here’s a great article with some tips on how to improve your communication skills as a data scientist.
Switching career paths from academia to data science can be very intimidating and might leave you in doubt about your ability to succeed as a data scientist.

The good news is, you already have most of the skills you need to become a data scientist. These include data handling, statistical analysis, literature review, problem-solving, and communication skills.

In fact, I was once told that I am already considered a data scientist just by possessing these skills, even though I wasn’t familiar with python (and coding in general) back then. This speaks to how important and crucial these skills are for data science.
Always remember that learning never ends, keep studying and practicing to polish these skills.
“It’s not what you are that holds you back, it’s what you think you are not.” -Denis Waitley
